title: Decidability Transfer via Specialization: Standard Conjecture D for Abelian Threefolds (Paper 52, Constructive Reverse Mathematics Series)
description:
Paper 52 of the Constructive Reverse Mathematics series. We prove that Standard Conjecture D (numerical equivalence implies homological equivalence) for abelian varieties A/Q of dimension g ≤ 3 follows from the Tate conjecture for divisors—which is unconditional by Tate (1966)—and the structural properties of the Lefschetz ring over finite fields, without invoking Standard Conjecture B or characteristic-0 Hodge theory.

The proof transfers decidability from characteristic p to characteristic 0 via the Fulton specialization map. The mechanism has three components: (i) the smooth proper base change isomorphism identifies homological triviality across characteristics; (ii) the Lefschetz ring of Ap has unconditionally definite primitive components (Milne 2002, via the Rosati involution); (iii) the liftable subspace U = im(sp) is stable under the Lefschetz operators L and Λ because the Fourier-Mukai transform specializes via the Poincaré bundle on the Néron model (Künnemann 1993, 1994). For g ≤ 3, all Tate classes are Lefschetz classes, yielding the transfer.

The argument fails sharply at dimension 4, where exotic Tate classes first appear outside the Lefschetz ring (Milne 2001). For each even g ≥ 6, Agugliaro (2025) constructs non-liftable exotic classes providing explicit counterexamples.

The logical transfer architecture is formalized in Lean 4 over Mathlib (4 source files, 369 lines). The bundle compiles with zero errors, zero warnings, and zero sorry. Both the core theorem (sub_lefschetz_non_degenerate) and the main theorem (decidability_transfer_g_le_3) use zero custom axioms. The three geometric inputs enter as hypotheses, not axioms, making both theorems pure logical implications.

Code is distributed exclusively via this Zenodo record.
